I'm seeing that sodium carbonate is a commonly used commercial meat tenderizer, and I wish to try some recipes featuring it.

In my country, baking soda is available anywhere while sodium carbonate isn't sold as a retail food stuff. Obviously I could use the video's method to make sodium carbonate and proceed that way.

However, I see one recipe recommending sodium carbonate but then pointing out that "in a pinch" baking soda can also be used. A more general-purpose advice page states: for every 12 ounces of meat, use 1 teaspoon of baking soda and 1/2 cup of water, and soak the meat for 15 minutes, THEN RINSE. There's no rinse stage mentioned in recipes using sodium carbonate.

My question is: do you chemist-types agree? Does adding sodium carbonate OR bicarbonate to water result in the same water chemistry? Or can you see a reason for me to fry up a batch of sodium carbonate? Do you see a reason to rinse one but not the other? Finally, how would I adjust volume? Cooking's not rocket science, so would say double the amount of baking soda be a reasonable substitute for sodium carbonate?

Very useful video. After some idle thought today I came up with the idea to convert baking soda into sodium hydroxide through a series of reactions. With this being the first step, this video provides a great guideline for me to work out the details of the process. Thanks for taking the time to make this and share it with us. Another process I read about was heating it in the oven at 200f for an hour. Which brings up a question I meant to ask. Why did you decide on 200c for the temperature? My understanding is that 50c is the temperature at which bicarb decomposes, though I would imagine you would want to heat it above boiling to drive off the water. Which makes me question how well the oven method would work at 200f. Either way, I think I'll be using your method when I do this.
